raw_text:
Mallon wades into NE vote battle
 
 Middlesbrough mayor Ray Mallon has been drafted in to boost the Yes campaign as the North East assembly referendum enters its final week.
 
 The former police chief, dubbed Robocop for his zero tolerance style, clashed on Thursday with Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron. Mr Mallon said an assembly would give local people more of a say over key issues such as transport and crime. But Mr Herron said North East people did not want or need an assembly.
 
 The pair met on the platform at Sunderland station as Mr Mallon toured the region highlighting claimed improvements to transport if the area gets an assembly. But Mr Herron - who gained fame as one of Sunderland's "metric martyrs" and is running his own No campaign alongside the official North East Says No campaign - said he was not convinced by Mr Mallon's arguments. "The reality is that it is not going to deliver," he said. "Labour has had two-and-a-half years to convince people of this. If you can't sell a deal in that time, it is a bad deal." On Wednesday, Mr Mallon provoked fury by branding the official No Campaign "two-bit Tories" in a confrontation outside its Durham headquarters. "The campaign is being run by two-bit Conservatives who are not interested in what happens in the North East; they are interested in hitting the Labour party over the head," he said. Mr Mallon is a late recruit to the Yes campaign after rejecting overtures from No campaigners including, he claims, Tory leader Michael Howard.
 
 Most local observers believe the contest is too close to call, although little recent polling has been carried out. Yes campaign chairman John Tomaney said he hoped for a late flurry of votes to boost turnout - something he says will boost their cause. He added: "The government exerts a lot of political power in the North East. The accountability should be in the North East as well." He also defended the decision to attack the official No campaign's alleged political allegiances. "We felt we had to show what people were behind the No campaign - London Tory spin doctors." Graham Robb, spokesman for North East Says No, said the Yes campaign's decision to get personal dragged the campaign "into the gutter" and showed they were "rattled". And he hit back at Mr Mallon's claim that an assembly would improve transport links in the region. "It can push paper around but it can not get people moving," he said. Some 487,939 people had returned their ballot papers by Wednesday - a turnout of 25.7%. The deadline for voting is next Thursday, 4 November.
llama3.2:1b:
Ray Mallon, Middlesbrough mayor, has been drafted into the North East assembly referendum as part of the "Yes" campaign to boost turnout and influence key issues such as transport. However, he clashed with Neil Herron, a Sunderland No campaigner, who claims that the region's residents do not want or need an assembly. 

Mallon argued that an assembly would give local people more control over certain issues. However, Herron responded that Labour has failed to convince voters of this in two years and that they are interested in hitting the opposition rather than working together.

The contest is seen as too close to call, but recent polls suggest a late surge in votes could boost turnout. The No campaign's chairman defended their decision to attack the official Yes campaign and claim that an assembly would not improve transport links.
llama3.2:3b: Ray Mallon, former police chief and Middlesbrough mayor, has been recruited to boost the Yes campaign in the North East assembly referendum. He clashed with Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron, saying an assembly would give local people more of a say over issues like transport and crime. However, Herron said he was not convinced by Mallon's arguments, calling the deal "a bad one" that had failed to persuade voters in two-and-a-half years. The contest is seen as too close to call, with little recent polling data available, and both sides are engaging in a heated battle over transport links and the campaign's tactics.
gemma2:2b:
Ray Mallon joined the Yes campaign to promote an assembly in the North East as part of its final week.  Mallon argued that it would give local people more control over key issues. Neil Herron, a member of the No campaign, disagreed and said he wasn't convinced by Mallon's arguments. 
There was disagreement between both sides during their public appearances in Sunderland station; including accusations from Mr Mallon against the official No Campaign.  The debate is too close to call, with late votes expected to boost turnout for the Yes campaign.  While the Yes campaign believes it will increase accountability and local control, the No campaign feels that it won't solve issues related to transport or everyday life. 
The North East Says No campaign has defended their actions against the accusations of political allegiances made by the Yes Campaign.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Mallon and Herron clash at Yes campaign debate in North East, raising questions about the feasibility of an assembly referendum. Maller says improvements to transport will make people more involved in their local governance, but argues they are not necessary; he claims the official No campaign is ineffective due to political manipulation by London Tory spin doctors. A late arrival for a Yes vote, Tomaney hopes early voting boosts turnout and shows how his party's influence in Northern England works. Robb accuses the Yes campaign of rancour over alleged ties with London Tories and of attacking the "London Tory spin doctors" who are pushing an assembly to improve regional transport links.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Middlesbrough mayor Ray Mallon has been drafted into the North East assembly referendum battle as the Yes campaign ramps up its efforts to boost turnout in the final days before the vote on November 4th. Mallon, who clashed with Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron earlier, argues an assembly would improve transport and address local issues like crime but Herron remains unconvinced. The contest is seen as too close to call, with polls indicating a narrow advantage for Yes campaigners despite recent accusations of political bias from the official No campaign.
qwen2.5:3b: Mallon has been recruited to boost the Yes campaign ahead of the North East assembly referendum's final week. Former police chief Mallon argues an assembly would give locals more say over issues like transport and crime, while Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron contends that people do not want or need one. The contest is seen as too close to call but may be boosted by a late surge in votes. Critics of the Yes campaign argue they are resorting to personal attacks after being discredited for their alleged political affiliations. Some 487,939 ballots have been returned with just over two weeks until the deadline.
opencoder:1.5b: Mallon wades into the North East vote battle. The former police chief dubbed Robocop has clashed with an assembly referendum. He said the North East people do not want or need an assembly. The pair met at Sunderland station on Thursday highlighting improvements to transport if the area gets an assembly. Mr Herron provoked fury by branding the official No Campaign "two-bit Tories." Labour party supporters grapple with Mr Mallon's arguments and expect a late flurry of votes to boost turnout - but it is not due until next Wednesday.

tinyllama:1.1b: Ahead of the final week of polling for the North East region's upcoming assembly referendum, the Mayor of the South Shields constituency, Ray Mallon, has been invited to meet with the No campaigner Neil Herrin to discuss transport links and crime, while some local observers believe that the vote is too close to call. Despite a recent poll indicating a 1% swing in favour of Yes, the official North East Say's No campaign remains confident of winning. Although some have criticised the campaign for its tone and approach, the No campaign has hit back with accusations that it's political allies are trying to exert undue influence on the campaign. The Yes campaign is expected to continue to push personal attacks and insinuate the official No campaign as being ineffectual in addressing local issues.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In this text, the main topic discussed is a North East referendum election, which is taking place in the region and involves two campaigns: an official Yes and a local No campaign. The official Yes campaign is led by Ray Mallon, while the local No campaign is led by Neil Herron. The two parties have had differing opinions on what promises they can deliver if their referendum results are in favor of the regional assembly.
phi:2.7b: The debate between Middlesbrough mayor Ray Mallon and Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron centers on the North East assembly referendum. Mr Mallon argues that an assembly would give more say to local people over issues such as transport and crime, while Mr Herron believes North East residents do not want or need an assembly. They clashed on a train platform in front of Sunderland station as Mr Mallon highlighted improvements to transport with claimed benefits from an assembly. However, Mr Herron is unconvinced by Mr Mallon's arguments and believes it is a bad deal. Most observers believe the contest is too close to call, but Mr Tomaney hopes for a late surge in votes to boost turnout. Yes campaign chairman John Tomaney argues that local people deserve more accountability and blames the No campaign for being run by "London Tory spin doctors." Mr Robb of North East Says No claims that the Yes campaign has dragged itself into the gutter with personal attacks on the No campaign's alleged political allegiances, but Mr Robb believes it is too late to make a difference. On Wednesday, he attacked Mr Mallon for calling the official No Campaign "two-bit Tories."

He clashed with Neil Herron, Sunderland No campaigner, on Thursday. The official No Campaign is being run by two-bit Conservatives, according to Mr Mallon. The contest is too close to call, but little recent polling has been carried out. The Yes campaign believes an assembly would give local people more of a say over key issues such as transport and crime.

Mallon opposes Sunderland No campaigner Neil Herron, who suggests that North East people do not want or need an assembly. Despite this disagreement, both Mallon and Herron acknowledge the close contest in the vote.

Mallon was brought into the Yes campaign after rejecting overtures from No campaigners including Michael Howard. Local observers believe the contest is too close to predict, although there has been little recent polling. The Yes campaign chairman, John Tomaney, hopes for a late surge of votes to boost turnout and strengthen their cause.

Graham Robb, spokesman for North East Says No, countered Mallon's claim that an assembly would improve transport links in the region by stating that while pushing paper around can be useful, it cannot get people moving. Some 7% of people had returned their ballot papers by Wednesday, and voting is scheduled to end on Thursday, November 4th.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Middlesbrough mayor Ray Mallon, known for his zero-tolerance approach as a former police chief, has entered the final week of the North East assembly referendum campaign to support the Yes side. He argues that an assembly would enhance local influence on transport and crime issues. However, Sunderland's No campaigner Neil Herron disagrees, asserting that the North East doesn't desire or require an assembly. Mallon and Herron clashed at Sunderland station, with Mallon highlighting claimed improvements to transport due to an assembly.

Mallon previously labeled the official No campaign "two-bit Tories," a statement met with fury from North East Says No spokesman Graham Robb, who accused the Yes campaign of resorting to personal attacks and showing signs of rattling. Robb dismissed Mallon's claim that an assembly would improve transport, stating it cannot move people effectively.

The contest is seen as too close to predict, with recent polling scarce. By Wednesday, 25.7% of eligible voters had returned their ballots. The deadline for voting is November 4th.
